title: harry meghan masks lockdown hike
story: PRINCE Harry and Meghan take a hike with their dogs on a public trail used by hundreds of walkers in locked-down LA.The Sussexes wore bandanas over their faces to protect against killer coronavirus in the first picture of them since their move to the city.The couple, who left baby Archie at home, had parked in a house-lined street before heading out on to the well-trodden community route popular with locals.A security guard with a rucksack kept watch on the pair as they exercised their beagle, Guy, and black labrador Oz for an hour.Another guard sat in a car near the trail. Harry, , protected himself from the heat in a brown baseball cap, sunglasses, a grey T-shirt and brown suede shoes.Meghan, , who was carrying a gold-plated iPhone and a bottle of sanitiser, also wore shades and a baseball cap, as well as white trousers, a black top and trainers.They both used blue bandanas to comply with new Calornia regulations on face coverings to combat the spread of coronavirus.A source told The Sun: “Harry and Meghan seemed in very good spirits and the dogs were clearly over the moon to be out and about.“They were hiking for over an hour and when they got back to the car the dogs looked exhausted.“Meghan even had to carry the beagle back because he was so worn out from the heat. There was one security guard with them ­during the hike.When they got back, they put the dogs in the trunk and Meghan drove off.”The couple relocated to Meghan’s home town last month from their £million bolthole on Vancouver Island in Canada.They have said their security will be “privately funded” following a row over cost to the UK taxpayer but details have not been released.The hike came just hours after the pair delivered free meals in West Hollywood for charity Project Angel Food, which is helping ­critically ill people who are at greater risk from Covid-.Recipient Dan Tyrell, , who has HIV, said: “For Harry and Meghan to do this is amazing.”He said he suspected “something was going on” when he saw two blacked-out xs on the road outside but did not let on he recognised the couple as he “didn’t want to make them uncomfortable”.Project Angel boss Richard Ayoub said Meghan got the idea to help them from her mum Doria.He added: “We’re completely honoured. They were extremely down to earth and genuinely interested in every single person they met.“They really wanted to go visit these people. They wanted to see them and talk to them and hopefully put a smile on their faces.”It is believed Harry and Meghan are still looking for a home in the posh area of Malibu by the Pacic.The Sun revealed yesterday how they had walked away from talks over actor Mel Gibson’s £million mansion in the coastal city.Safe from prying eyes with acres of private gardens for the dogs and Archie to enjoy.The best security in the world on hand.Harry could have been happy in the knowledge he was close to Windsor Castle where his -year-old grandfather and grandmother the Queen, who celebrates her th birthday on Tuesday are in residence.Instead he and Meghan are in Los Angeles, the biggest celebrity hang out in the world.You don’t get much more famous than Meghan and Harry.They can hardly complain about privacy when they choose to live in the heart of celebrity country.If they had not been so hasty, they could be planning their future in the secure,  peaceful place Harry still regards as home.I cannot see the sense in it.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: charles ingram where is he now
story: The ex-Army Major was found guilty of swindling the show with the help of his we Diana and a coughing accomplice, Tecwen Whittock.Born in Shardlow, Derbyshire, in , Ingram obtained a degree in civil engineering and a Masters in corporate management before joining the Army in .He became an officer with the Royal Engineers and rose to the rank of Major in .Ingram served in Bosnia for six months on Nato peacekeeping duties.He was forced to resign from the Army in August  following his court case.Diana Ingram married Charles in .The couple met while she was training to be a teacher at Barry College in South Wales, going on to have three children.She had already appeared on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire  prior to her husbands appearances, winning £, - the same as her brother Adrian Pollock also won.In , Major Charles Ingram answered  questions correctly to sensationally scoop the jackpot on Who Wants to Be a Millionaire  but the cheque was taken from him as he left the studio as suspicions began to surface.A court ruled he had answered the questions through help from fellow contestant Tecwen Whittock, who coughed to alert him to the right answers.Ingrams we was also said to be involved.Whittock, a college lecturer from Cardf, was waiting in the fastest finger first group when the controversy erupted.A few days after the show, Ingram received a message to call Paul Smith, the boss of the company which made the show.Mr Smith said there were irregularities during the taping of the show and it would not be aired.Police had also been contacted.It was suggested Whittock had been coughing loudly to indicate the right answer, and blew his nose loudly when the major was about to give a wrong answer.Pagers and mobile phones had been used to help, it was claimed.The  Southwark Crown Court trial lasted four weeks and heard evidence from Ingram claiming the video tape of the show was unfairly manipulated.He insisted he didnt notice the coughing but  coughs were recorded during the second night of the show -  from the ten Fastest Finger First contestants, with  of these signicant.Prosecutors said these coughs were from Whittock, who claimed to have suffered a persistent cough for his entire le.All three were convicted of procuring the execution of a valuable security by deception on April , .Both Diana and Charles were given an  month prison sentence suspended for two years, while Whittock received a  month sentence suspended for two years.After he was sentenced, the Army Board forced Ingram to resign as major after  years of service.Despite this, he went on to remain a TV personality and made several appearances on competition reality shows.He took part in The Weakest Link with his we Diane, while he also competed in The Game alongside former Liberty X singer Kevin Simm.Charles starred in Channel s We Swap, where he swapped his we for Jade Goody.It emerged in  that Ingram paid only £, of the £, fine he was given in  — despite his court case costing the taxpayer more than £million.He retreated to his home in Westbury, Wilts, selling jewellery made by Diana on a market stall.In October , The Sun revealed he was flogging homemade brooches for £ and necklaces for up to £.The Sun tracked down the cheat and found him loading up his belongings into a van to move to a flat on a remote farm.He decided to sell his £, country home after the scandal turned him into a recluse.Charles was last spotted selling jewellery in a Christmas market stall in Bath in , he had declared himself as bankrupt for the fourth time just months before.After ITV show Quiz aired on ITV, Charles tweeted about the actor Matthew Macfadyen, who plays him, saying: Matthew is so damn good-looking I can’t sleep. title: debenhams uk store closures latest
story: It comes after the department store chain fell into administration for the second time in  months.The following seven stores will shut, with  jobs being cut in the process.The department store chain hasnt given an exact date for when the shops will close, ortheyll reopen at all once the coronavirus lockdown has lted.These stores are in:Debenhams said it has done deals with landlords on a majority of its  stores, but said a handful more could be at risk.Earlier this month, the department store chain revealed it would shut  shops, along with  of its branches in Ireland, after falling into administration.Debenhams told The Sun that the plan to close  stores remains, but added that the intention was there would still be at least  stores in the UK.The retailer had already closed  stores in January , including Altrincham, Wolverhampton, Ashford and Wimbledon.The Sun is also checking how many stores its closed in total over the past few years and well update this story as soon as we get a response.Debenhams hasnt announced the locations of any other store planned closures.All Debenhams UK stores are currently closed in line with government guidance following the coronavirus outbreak.Debenhams went into administration in April .Its the second time the department store chain has gone bust in a year and also follows a company voluntary arrangement- a type of insolvency process.Debenhams has appointed business advisory firm FRP Advisory to oversee the process.The -year-old retailer last entered administration in April .Back then, a group of banks and hedge funds led by US firm Silver Point Capital took control of the struggling retailer which wiped out the investments of shareholders, including Sports Direct billionaire Mike Ashley.But stores remained open and the retailer says this time round it will work to re-open as many stores as possible when coronavirus related lockdown restrictions are lted.Debenhams website is currently trading as normal and it even has a half price Easter sale on.Stefaan Vansteenkiste, chief executive officer of Debenhams, said: The appointment of the administrators will protect our business, our employees, and other important stakeholders, so that we are in a position to resume trading from our stores.We are desperately sorry not to be able to keep the Irish business operating but are faced with no alternative option in the current environment.Customers are still able to spend their gt cards online and in storesas normal.But shoppers might want to consider using any gt cards they have while the retailer is still accepting them.Debenhams points out that online, you can only use one gt card per transaction.Returns are still being accepted as usual.But again, you might want to consider ing or exchanging items sooner rather than later to be on the safe side - thatsyoure able to do so safely during lockdown.You should also consider putting new purchases on credit card as this will give you greater protectionsomething goes wrong with the purchase and youre unable to get your money back from Debenhams.Debit card purchases also offer some protection, but not to the same extent as those offered by credit cards.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHow well has the Government handled coronavirus  The outbreak is the biggest ­challenge faced by the country since the Second World War. It has required a huge economic bailout and an immense effort by the NHS, care staff and other key workers.But has the response by Boris Johnson ’s administration been adequate Here our experts look at what the Government got right and what they got wrong, and deliver their verdicts. Lockdown WHAT THEY GOT RIGHT We managed to introduce lockdown measures without shutting vital public spaces. This approach has managed to maintain extremely high levels of public support for the measures. Covid- victims are infecting on average fewer than one person each – the crucial “R” reproduction number threshold which,social distancing is maintained, will kill off the outbreak. This has been achieved while keeping most parks open and allowing daily exercise. By contrast, Italy shut public spaces entirely from mid-March, which exacerbated mental health problems in the population. No also made a good call in using experts to sell its social distancing message. England’s Chief Medical Officer Prof Chris Whitty and Chief Scientic Adviser Sir Patrick Vallance have been vital in maintaining public trust. WHAT THEY GOT WRONG We introduced lockdown measures slower than almost all of Europe. The Government’s mantra on this is that it is “guided by the science” – but in reality, such decisions are a judgment call by politicians. The Prime Minister and his Cabinet decide which experts on its Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies to listen to most and then interpreted their advice. In mid-January, when China locked down Wuhan, few thought it would happen in liberal Europe. By early March, many countries were shutting down. But here, Boris Johnson was still joking about shaking hands with patients on a hospital visit. The PM and his team got updated modelling that triggered a U-turn on March . Data from Italy suggested that unless we were also locked down immediately, , people would die in a matter of months. Now, our death rate per capita is twice that in Ireland and we are tipped to have Europe’s worst outbreak. VERDICT An increasing number of experts believe we acted too slowly – but a final assessment is only possible with full data after the pandemic. Testing WHAT THEY GOT RIGHTWe were one of the first countries to develop its own coronavirus test.Public Health England’s swab test was used to contain the outbreak as patients were isolated after ing from abroad. Detailed contact tracing was then carried out so everyone in contact with a confirmed case could also be isolated. This delayed widespread community transmission and is the main reason we are two or three weeks behind the likes of Italy and Spain in outbreak trajectory. Hospital bed numbers were low at the start of the outbreak but this swt action bought the NHS time, enabling temporary Nightingale hospitals to be set up. Intensive care was also kept within capacity in the first wave. WHAT THEY GOT WRONG The March  decision to abandon widespread community testing shocked scientists. This was the start of the much-disputed “herd immunity” phase of the strategy. It went directly against World Health Organisation advice for governments to “test, test, test”. The decision came amid an initial clamour for tests by the general public from GPs. From this point, only the most seriously ill patients in hospitals were tested. It soon became clear other countries were outstripping our testing capacity. Germany was achieving remarkably low death rates after scaling up testing using private labs. The UK decided to initially only use PHE’s Colindale lab before some NHS labs were kitted out to do swab analysis. While we were withdrawing from the arms race on testing, other countries were building up supplies needed to analyse the swabs. And as the Government came under pressure to ramp up testing, lack of supplies hampered efforts. VERDICT The decision to axe community testing and contact-tracing means we have no reliable data on how widespread Covid is outside of hospitals – which could delay an end to lockdown. PPE - personal protective equipment    WHAT THEY GOT RIGHT The Government says we have enough personal protective equipmentfor all who need it. But it admits there have been distribution problems, hampering efforts to deliver equipment where it needs to go. Since the beginning of the outbreak,  million pieces of PPE have been delivered to the front line. The Royal College of Physicians has said a combination of revised PPE guidance issued two weeks ago by Public Health England, plus the NHS drive to get millions more pieces of kit to the front line, had made a big impact on the shortages and helped to allay the fears of workers. WHAT THEY GOT WRONG To frontline doctors and nurses, it doesn’t really make a dference what caused the problem. Hospital trusts are reporting “critically low” supplies, with the British Medical Association reporting “dangerously low levels” in some parts of the country. A survey by the Royal College of Surgeons found a third of surgeons did not have access to enough masks, gowns and other equipment. And a BMA survey last week found half of doctors felt pressured to work in high-risk areas despite not having adequate PPE. VERDICT Whatever the cause of the shortages, the Government either did not recognise the scale of the problem or it did not respond to it quickly enough. The economy    WHAT THEY GOT RIGHTIT is a month since Chancellor Rishi Sunak ’s Budget pledge of £billion for coronavirus-hit companies.Smaller firms were promised emergency cash through the Coronavirus Business Interruption Loans Scheme while big companies could access funds via the Covid Corporate Financing Facility. That is without the Government’s Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme, where firms can reclaim % of workers’ wages, up to £, a month. WHAT THEY GOT WRONG ONLY just over , smaller firms have had loans through the CBILS, out of , that managed to apply. There have been more than , enquiries. Banks are accused of failing to respond, dragging their feet, making business owners jump through hoops, or in some cases unfairly rejecting applications.  Around £.billion of CBILS loans have been approved. Together with the £.billion loaned through the CCFF, it is .% of the £billion earmarked by the Chancellor. Amid criticism, Mr Sunak has now launched the Coronavirus Large Business Interruption Loan Scheme for firms that could not access either pot of money. VERDICT The Job Retention Scheme could be a game-changer in preventing millions more workers getting the chop. But the go-slow on loans for firms is a cause for concern, especially with , companies already in trouble. Care homes

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBusiness Secretary Alok Sharma has not ruled out comment by a junior Health Minister that Britain may only exit lock down when a vaccine is produced. Nadine Dorries earlier this week claimed the only way the UK will exit full lockdown is when a vaccine for Covid- is found. Mr Sharma announced that the government was launching a vaccine taskforce, with top boffins still fearing a vaccine coudl be - months away. Led by chief scientic adviser Sir Patrick Vallance, and deputy chief medical officer Professor Jonathan van Tam, it will support efforts to rapidly develop a vaccine as soon as possible. But asked about Ms Dorries comments at todayaposs Downing St press conference Mr Sharma did not answer the question directly. Instead he said that on the lockdown the government would be guided by the evidence. Mr Sharma also said: We cannot put a date on when we will get a vaccine. But, we live in a country with a rich history of pioneering science. He added: Producing a vaccine is a colossal undertaking. A complex process which will take many months. There are no guarantees. But the Government is backing our scientists, betting big to maximise the chance of success.Mrs Dorries, Health Minister for Patient Safety, Suicide Prevention and Mental Health, made the claims on Twitter.She tweeted: Journalists should stop asking about an ‘exit strategy.’ There is only one way we can ‘exit’ full lockdown and that is when we have a vaccine. Until then, we need to find ways we can adapt society and strike a balance between the health of the nation and our economy.

We were reminded of that this week when the Government announced the lockdown must continue for at least another three weeks. For many this will have been a dficult moment as they brace themselves for yet more time away from loved ones. Others will be anxious about when their children willto school or fearful they will not have a job or business toto when the restrictions are finally lted. We must all draw strength from the fact this heroic national effort is beginning to pay idends. There are signs the rate of infections is starting to plateau.Sadly, we will have to steel ourselves for the loss of more lives. But amid the grief there have been moments of light. The way the whole country claps for carers each Thursday has boosted morale. And no one has captured the imagination of the country more than Captain Tom Moore whose efforts have now raised more than £million for NHS charities. These acts of kindness have lted our spirits at this most challenging of times. Class issue All parents want their children to go to a good local school. But the latest figures show an increase in the number of families failing to land a place at their first-choice primary.  Families on low incomes are not in a position to game the system by buying properties in exclusive catchment areas. They often end up having to send their kids to schools miles from home, requiring long journeys by public transport. It is a reminder that a good education for all should be a right, not a luxury.   vision

title: coronavirus expert shares harsh reality
story: NewsCoronavirus: Expert shares harsh reality of number of people who will die in UKProfessor Anthony Costello warned the government was too slow with a number of things and UK deaths from Covid- could reach to ,, as calls continue for more NHS workers to be testedShareCommentsByHarriet LineJamie Hawkins:,  APR NewsProfessor Anthony Costello said the harsh reality is that we were too slow with a number of things " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBritain will face further waves of Covid- and will probably have the highest death rate in Europe because the Government was too slow to act, a leading physician has warned. Professor Anthony Costello, of University College Londonaposs Institute for Global Health, told a committee of MPs that the harsh reality is that we were too slow with a number of things and deaths could reach to ,.His comments came as the Department of Health said a total of , patients have died in hospital after testing positive for coronavirus in the UK as of pm on Thursday, up by  from the day before.Prof Costello said: If weaposre going to suppress the chain of transmission of this virus in the next stage we all hope that the national lockdown and social distancing will bring about a large suppression of the epidemic so far - but weaposre going to face further waves. And so we need to make sure that we have a system in place that cannot just do a certain number of tests in the laboratory, but has a system at district and community level. Prof Costello, giving evidence to the Commons Health and Social Care Committee, said we should not have any blame at this stage but that we can make sure in the second wave weaposre not too slow. Health Secretary Matt Hancock announced that testing will be expanded to those in the police, fire service and prisons, as well as critical local authority workers, the judiciary and Department for Work and Pensions staff where required.  It follows criticism of a gulf between those being tested and the testing capacity, with just , tests being conducted in the  hours up to am on Thursday, despite , tests being available. Mr Hancock confirmed to the committee that more than , NHS workers have now been tested for coronavirus, and admitted he would love to be able to wave a magic wand to increase supplies of personal protective equipment . MPs were also told that healthcare staff are genuinely concerned about the safety of patients being compromisedworkers are spread too thinly. Dr Alison Pittard, Dean at the Faculty of Intensive Care Medicine, said: Weaposve had to spread ourselves more thinly and we have developed guidance to try and make sure that continues to be safe, butwe have to expand even more and spread ourselves even more thinly, there would be concern that safety could be compromised.  So everyone is working really well, weaposre doing everything that we can but staff are genuinely concerned. Dame Donna Kinnair, chief executive of the Royal College of Nursing, told the committee sick NHS workers are being forced to drive two hours away to be tested. She urged: We need some really clear direction on how we can access testing both in the NHS but more so for social care, because they donapost have the same infrastructure as the NHS. Prof Costello, a former British director at the World Health Organisation, said he was not sure we need , tests per day in realitywe can get this epidemic damped down and that it was more important to have the systems in place. How are they restructuring the public health teams  Have they got plans in place Will they need extra volunteers, for example He also suggested offering incentives to % of the population to stay socially isolated in order to get the economy going again. We have to get the economy going andit means locking down % of our population, even giving them incentives to stay in quarantine and with digital apps to help monitor their symptoms and give them support, thataposs the way to really keep this going until we get a vaccine and safe herd immunity.The committeeaposs chairman Jeremy Hunt later called for a massive ramp-up - not just in the testing, but also the tracing of everyone who has been in contact with someone who has the virus. He told BBC Radio aposs World At One programme: If weaposre going to be in a position where we can track and trace every single person who has Covid or might have had Covid in three weeksapos time, because thataposs when we could next potentially end the lockdown, well that is a huge logistical undertaking. Mr Hunt added: If weaposre going to copy the best in the world then that is what we now need to do.

title: inside make shift coronavirus mortuary
story: NewsInside make-sht coronavirus mortuary built in days that holds  bodiesThe site off a residential street in Bristol contains six chilled containers that are covered by a large gazebo to deal with a potential extra demand from coronavirus Covid- deathsShareCommentsByTom Bevan:,  APR NewsThe mortuary was built in Bristol to increase capacity during coronavirus " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email These are the first pictures inside a make-sht mortuary that was built in less than a week to increase capacity during the coronavirus.The site in Bristol is designed to deal with a potential extra demand for a dignied site where bodies can be stored ahead of funerals. The marquee, which has been built at a vehicle depot, can accommodate up to  bodies. It was completed earlier this week and contains six chilled containers that are covered by a large gazebo. Faith leaders and a humanist gathered for a ceremony today to offer thoughts and prayers for those who might need to use the site and their families during the pandemic. The event was also attended by Mayor of Bristol Marvin Rees. Mr Rees said: “This is a dficult time for everyone in our city and we know the reason for building this place of rest is distressing for our communities. It’s important we take all preparations necessary so we can provide a dignied place to rest for citizens who sadly lose their lives during the Covid- pandemic. “Today’s event exemplied kindness, respect and dignity. It’s reassuring to see representatives from a range of faiths and non-faiths coming together today. I hope it gives some comfort to all our residents that we will do all we can to support each other through this dficult time. “We stand with people from all faiths and no faith because We Are Bristol together.” Hospitals across the UK have increased their general capacity for patients who died over the last few weeks but local councils have been working to be preparedfurther space is needed. This was one of the first times members of the public have been allowed inside. The council said they allowed dferent faiths from across the city to view the site as they wanted to be open and transparent about the preparations it was making. Representatives from dferent religions gave a prayer while a leading humanist also gave a reading to a small gathering inside.  Although no funeral services will take place at the site, Bristol City Council said it held the ceremony so faith and non-faith representatives can help bereaved people better understand the process. The council said it had been quickly established to ensure sufficient capacity to allow for dignity and respect to be maintained before funerals are held. Attendees at the event included The Bishop of Bristol Vivienne Faull virtually over Zoom, The Buddhist Chaplin at the University of Bristol, Sister Jinho, Humanist Celebrant Chrissie Hackett, and Zaheer Shabir, represented the Muslim community. A number of other faith leaders, unable to attend in person, also joined the ceremony by Zoom, including Rabbi Monique Mayer and Hindu representative, Shiv Sama. Restrictions will be in place at the site to protect staff who will be offered continued emotional support.  The site is not yet in use and Bristol City Council has written to neighbours around the site to keep them informed. The tented site is located off a residential street, but vehicles will reverse into a covered area to ensure all dignity is maintained. Those transporting the body would stop at an infection control point and the deceased would be transferred in the same way as a traditional mortuary to be stored in one of six refrigerated containers until they are removed for a funeral. There is a three pronged walkway for staff to use to ensure infection control and PPE wearing is carried out and strict instructions on following safety measures. Mortuary and coroneraposs support manager for Bristol City Council John Pitchers, said: The purpose-built facility is to ensure there is sufficient capacity to continue to look after the deceased in a way that ensures dignity and respect. We all hope it is never needed butit is, it is vital that we can continue to deliver the same care.  It is designed to be as close as possible to a traditional morgue. Within the containers are the same wrappers as in a permanent one. The procedures are all the same and anyone using it will be moved around with the same equipment. They are kept safe and the level of security is the same. It is essentially ready now but we are limited to the number of people we can accommodate until the racking is here which is due to arrive at the end of next week. Any deceased comes through the main door and there is strict infection control. The van reverses and the bodies are transferred into the temporary resting place. There is a three stage process for staff with walkways to ensure all safety measures are carried out. Bristol City Council said it originally purchased containers which could accommodate  deceased during usual operation. It has also ordered bespoke racking which could increase this capacityrequired, and decisions will be made later on according to levels of demand. Bristol Mayor Marvin Rees said: I never thought I would have to deal with this kind of issue as mayor.

title: man who drove 55 miles
story: NewsMan who drove  miles to exercise shares explanation after police angerStephen, , has hit back at police officers who imposed strict social distancing measures on him despite his serious health condition saying he had no idea what he was doingShareCommentsByLottie Gibbons:,  APR NewsStephen says police coronavirus measures were used inappropriately against him" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA man who became embroiled in a debate with police after driving  miles to exercise has said he broke lockdown rules for a serious health condition. Stephen, , drove from Liverpool to Pendle Hill to climb a steep hill and was forced tohome by officers who found him in Barley on April .But Stephen has hit back after the ordeal, saying he needs exercise due to his high blood pressure to keep him off medication, reports the Liverpool Echo. At the time, Ribble Valley Police said: Today we have removed an inidual who thought it was okay to drive from Liverpool to Barley to walk up Pendle Hill. His justication for this was his local hills were ‘closed to the public’ and he needs to exercise as he has high blood pressure. This man was ill-equipped for the task and clearly not physically fit enough to tackle what was in front of him. It was below freezing this morning and whilst it was a beautully clear day he had no idea of the route terrain or direction back to his car once he had got to the top. If he made it all. No map, no compass, no fluids and no idea...However, Stephen believes the implementation of the government’s coronavirus emergency powers towards him was inappropriate. Speaking to the ECHO , Stephen, a civil engineer, said he suffers from hypertension and has only recently come off medication for the condition.He said: An essential and ongoing combination of weight loss and regular exercise has resulted in my being able to manage my hypertension without the need for prescribed medication. However, the regular exercise concerned consists of regularly walking steep inclines as I cannot run or jog due to cartilage problems in my left knee.  Previously, Stephen said he was travelling to Moel Famau and Loggerheads Park in North Wales once or twice a week to perform such exercise. But due to recent Covid- restrictions, these sites have temporarily closed, which Stephen says meant he had to venture to Pendle Hill in Lancashire instead. At the start of his walk, Stephen says he was flagged down my a marked police vehicle, who enquired whether he had parked his car on the road. Stephen said: I turned to address the officer and was met with an exclamation of stay back, don’t come any closer. I was about ten feet away from the officer at this point, who remained in the vehicle. I confirmed that the car on the road was mine. The officer then askedI had driven from Liverpool.  I was having trouble hearing the officer, due to the noise of the vehicle engine, and endeavoured to take up a position at the side of the vehicle, whilst maintaining an appropriate distance, so I could hear him better but was met with another caustic exclamation of don’t come any closer, I won’t tell you again. Stephen says he then explained to the officer his medical condition and how upon research Pendle Hill had not been identied as a closed site for visitors. Following a further conversation, Stephen says was he was asked to leave the area immediately. Stephen says he was left saddened by what he believes to be aposinappropriate and completely disproportionateapos behaviour of the police. He said: It was never my intention to obstruct the officer in the execution of his duties in any way, nor fail to comply with the officer’s subsequent appraisal of the situation.  I was simply conversing with the officer in an attempt to explain the overarching circumstances and convey the fact that I had in fact travelled a ‘reasonable distance’ to the nearest available location able to facilitate my health requirements via appropriate exercise. He added: I am an experienced climber who was appropriately dressed and profoundly familiar with Pendle Hill. New government guidelines released to police yesterday state driving to the countryside and walking, when far more time is spent walking than driving is a reasonable excuse to leave the house for. A spokesperson for Lancashire Police said: We can confirm that we have received a complaint so it wouldn’t be appropriate to comment any further on this particular case at this time.

story: NewsNorth Korea working day and night on new hospital while denying Covid- casesWorkers are toiling to complete Pyongyang General Hospital in less than  days, despite North Korean authorities claiming that there are no coronavirus cases in the countryShareCommentsByMichael Havis:,  APR News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email North Korea workers are labouring “day and night” to build a new hospital “faster and better” than planned, as officials deny that coronavirus has crossed its borders.Work on the new Pyongyang General Hospital began suddenly just under a month ago, with Kim Jong-un setting an ambitious -day deadline for completion. However, he appeared to downplay any link to the ongoing pandemic at the time, making no reference to it at a groundbreaking ceremony and instead linking its completion to a national holiday. But now it looks like the project might be rushed to completion even sooner.Do you have a coronavirus story  Email webnews@mirrorAccording to state run media, builders are intent on completing construction “faster and better”, and are working “day and night” to get the hospital up and running. The report added that the “vicious” sanctions imposed by “hostile forces” to punish North Korea for its nuclear weapons programme were having no impact on progress. New images show that foundations had already been dug, concrete poured and metal structural supports installed.  In one photo construction can be seen continuing at night. The reason for the renewed urgency is not stated in the report, but experts agree that the building is coming together quickly. Martyn Williams and Peter Makoswky from North Korea watchdog,  North, analysed the project in satellite photos.  “Construction has continued at such pace that for the first time – after just under one month – the overall outline of the building is visible,” they wrote. “Commercial satellite imagery from April  shows clear outlines of the two towers that will dominate the rear of the hospital. “The rest of the building is also taking shape, including a distinctive lip that juts out from the front of the hospital.”  North Korea’s two closest neighbours have had tens of thousands of coronavirus cases, but the Kim regime says there has not been a single one within its borders. The claim cannot be independently veried in the closed-off country and has been met with scepticism.

title: starving toddler rare eating disorder
story: NewsStarving toddler with rare eating disorder gets le-saving KFC deliveryAkira Gujadhur, six, who has autism, can only eat popcorn chicken due to a rare medical condition, and with all KFC branches closed during coronavirus lockdown, she ran the risk of starvingShareCommentsByMatthew Dresch:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsAkira Gujadhur can only eat the bite-sized chunks of KFC" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA young girl at risk of starvation without KFC popcorn chicken has been given a monthaposs supply of it by the fast-food giant. Akira Gujadhur, six, suffers from a rare eating disorder meaning she refuses to eat anything but the bite-sized chunks of chicken.With all branches of KFC closed during the coronavirus lockdown her parents, Raj and Hem, feared the worst.But following an appeal for help, KFC agreed to deliver a huge batch of popcorn chicken to the familyaposs home in Poole, Dorset. Akira, who is autistic, refuses to eat chicken from the supermarket because of her Avoidant Restrictive Food Intake Disorder . Before the lockdown, her parents were buying her two portions a day from their local KFC, spending an estimated £, on popcorn chicken in total.  Akiraaposs consultant at St Thomasapos Hospital in London, where Boris Johnson was treated for coronavirus, even wrote a letter backing their appeal to KFC for assistance.In it, he has asked the fast food giantthey were able to sell frozen popcorn chicken to the family aposto ensure her nutritional status remains adequateapos. The pleas have now been answered and KFC. A spokesman for the company said the supply would by enough for another month and confirmed it was being offered free of charge. A KFC spokesperson said: Weaposve been in touch with Akiraaposs family and know what a challenging situation this is for them. We want to help out, so weaposre delivering some free popcorn chicken to see them through the next month. We hope it makes this time a little easier for Akira and her whole family. Mr Gujadhur said: This is very good news and I would like to say thank you to everyone involved. We were getting really, really anxious but now she wonapost starve.  This is such a relief. We had started giving her a little bit less each day so it didnapost run out. Akiraaposs condition originated when she suffered a severe throat infection at just eight-months-old which saw her stop eating. Doctors advised her parents to put dferent foods in front of her until she selected something. She chose a piece of popcorn chicken when she was nine-months-old and has refused to eat anything  since. Mr Gujadhur, a senior actuarial analyst for finance firm Capita, said: Before the lockdown, we invested in the same kitchen equipment that is used by KFC and cooked the KFC frozen popcorn chicken at the recommended temperature and cooking time.

She and Prince Harry are now settling into le in Los Angeles, after relocating from Vancouver Island in Canada to the US, where they were seen publicly for the first time delivering meals to residents who have been left vulnerable by the coronavirus pandemic.According to the source, Meghan lit up when talking about baby Archie in a recent conversation and joked that he might need a sibling.For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog hereShe joked that he needs a pint-size little buddy other than the dogs, they said. He spoke to families who are being supported by the childrenaposs charity WellChild, which he has been a patron of since , from his Calornia home. title: meghan markle says feels good
story: NewsMeghan Markle says it feels good being out and about connecting with people in LAMeghan and Harry made  visits delivering parcels for a cause dear to Meghans mum, Project Angel Food, in a bid to support their local community during the coronavirus crisisShareCommentsByMirror:,  APR NewsMeghan said it feels good to be out and about working with the community " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Meghan Markle has spoken out after delivering free meals in Los Angeles to people in isolation with Prince Harry, saying it was good to be “out and about connecting with people.”The couple were spotted delivering food parcels for two days to critically ill residents at risk of contracting COVID- and developing severe symptoms. The pair were seen wearing face masks, plastic gloves and carrying food bags as they visited blocks of flats - after saying they wanted to see the city “through the eyes of philanthropy” following their move from the UK.A source told DailyMail : “Some people didnapost recognize them at first and others were just completely shocked. One elderly woman actually started to cry and said she had always been a fan and had always wanted to meet them, and then welcomed them to their new le in America.”No-one at the apartments knew they were coming and had not been forewarned. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog here They added that the stealth mission to help people in need made the Duchess of Sussex ‘feel good’. “Meghan said it felt good to finally be out and about, connecting with people. “It was surreal and just so heartwarming. They brought so many smiles and made Easter so special for those who needed it the most.” The couple arrived at the Sierra Bonita Community Apartments, in West Hollywood, arriving in a x on Wednesday, when they were caught on CCTV. While Harry, , and Meghan, , were accompanied by security trailing them in an SUV, the pair walked to the apartments solo. One of the residents, Daniel Tyrell, , came down from his fourth-floor apartment to pick up food at the main entrance not recognising the couple at first.  Daniel, who has HIV, said: “My phone rang, and a lady said, ‘Hi this is Meghan from Project Angel Food.” “I said, ‘Oh, do you want to meet me downstairs ’ - I didn’t realise it was THE Meghan at this point.’ Daniel said he was shocked when he walked down the building’s external staircase and spotted two black-out SUVs on the road outside. “I knew they was something going on,” he added. As he approached the front door, Daniel said he spotted a man with ginger hair who looked familiar. “I recognised Harry first because I saw his red hair, but he didn’t say anything,” said Daniel.“Then I looked at Meghan and put it all together. “They both said here’s the food, hope you’re well. “I said, ‘Thank you’ and they handed the food over, then I did a double-take. “I didn’t say to them ‘Hey you’re the Royals’ or anything. “I think they’re wonderful, wonderful people and I am glad they are here in LA doing this.” The couple became involved in the project through Meghan’s mum, Doria Ragland, who has supported the charity and founder Marianne Williamson for many years. Doria first introduced Meghan to the teachings of Marianne when she was a teenager, when she gave her one of her most famous books called A Return to Love. The friend added: “She plans on volunteering much more with Harry and for the time being urged her mom to stay home and stay safe. “Doria is always wanting to help and be of service, so staying home can be a bit challenging.”

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMeghan Markle and Prince Harry have been photographed for the first time since they moved to LA as they delivered food parcels to people unable to go outside due to coronavirus. The couple wore facemasks and gloves as they dropped off packages on behalf of the Los Angeles-based nonprofit Project Angel Food to people with chronic illnesses. The couple, who were casually dressed in jeans, t-shirts, baseball caps and trainers, were caught on CCTV as they buzzed the front door at the Sierra Bonita Community Apartments in West Hollywood. The people they were delivering to had no warning of their famous helpers, and have revealed the kind words the couple said before handing over the food. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog here The delivered food to two residents, including Daniel Tyrell, , who came down from his fourth-floor apartment to pick up the delivery at the main entrance. Daniel, who has HIV and issues with high blood pressure, said: “My phone rang and a lady said, ‘Hi this is Meghan from Project Angel Food.’ “I said, ‘Oh, do you want to meet me downstairs ’  “I didn’t realise it was THE Meghan at this point. “So I walked down the external staircase and I saw the two black SUVs on the road outside so I knew there was something gong on. “I went down to the front door to let them in. “I recognised him first because of his reddish hair.  “Then I looked at her and put it together. “Harry didn’t introduce himself or anything. “They both said here’s the food and thank you, hope you’re well and that you’re fine. “They handed the food over and I said thank you, too. “I didn’t let on about it, I didn’t want to make them uncomfortable or anything.  The couple arrived in their black SUV and were followed by another car containing their protection officers. However they approached the front door alone. Daniel added: To have someone come and deliver the food is amazing, it makes us here feel that somebody cares outside. “It’s also good for me and us here to have the people contact, too, because we’re here and self isolating. “So for Harry and Meghan to do this is amazing. “I have been a client of Project Angel Food for two years and I am on a blood pressure diet, which helps me. “There’s two or three people in the building that get for from them.  “The deliveries usually come at . in the morning on a Wednesday, so when I got told it was being delivered later I thought that was strange.” After announcing their plans to quit the royal family in January, the couple fled to Canada but have now moved to LA where they plan to set up home. They are in the process of setting up a new charity venture, however have said it wonapost launch until the time is right.  Speaking about having Meghan and Harry in the city, Daniel said: “You know, I hope they get a better reception here in LA than they have in the UK. “They’re doing a great thing and I for one am very grateful.” Benita Hood, who manages the building, took the day off to attend a physio appointment and was gutted to miss the royal visitors.  Benita said: “I can’t believe I took the day off! “Oh my God I can’t believe they came to my building. “Nobody knew they were coming, we had no idea. This building is named after me. “There was no alert or anything.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A person with coronavirus could infect others around them simply by saying one or two words in a calm and normal voice, a new study suggests.When a Covid- carrier speaks, they emit tiny liquid droplets that contain infectious virus particles and could linger in the air - and be inhaled by others - for up to three hours, research has found. The droplets behave like an aerosol - a suspension of particles or droplets in air or another gas - and can penetrate deep into the lungs when they are breathed in, scientists found. A team from the US National Institutes of Health used a laser light-scattering experiment to demonstrate how droplets fill the air when a person speaks, and how masks can block them and prevent the spread of Covid-. Have you been affected by coronavirus  Email webnews@mirror.  The study was published in the New England Journal of Medicine. Molecular biologist Dr Matthew Meselson, of Hard University, wrote: Certain persons called apossuper spreadersapos produce many more aerosol particles than other persons. These particles are too small to settle because of gravity, but they are carried by air currents and dispersed by dfusion and air turbulence. Inhaled aerosolised particles can penetrate deep into the lungs and infect cells in the alveoli, air sacs in the lungs which exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide molecules to and from the bloodstream, the study found. The particles can be carried by drafts. Dr Meselson added: Aerosols from infected persons may therefore pose an inhalation threat even at considerable distances and in enclosed spaces, particularlythere is poor ventilation. The possible contribution of infective aerosols to the current pandemic suggests the advisability of wearing a suitable mask whenever it is thought that infected persons may be nearby and of providing adequate ventilation of enclosed spaces where such persons are known to be or may recently have been. The researchers said some studies have shown that the number of droplets produced by speaking is similar to the number produced by coughing.Masks can prevent the droplets from filling the air, the scientists said. A separate study in the New England Journal of Medicine in March found that aerosolised coronavirus could remain in the air for up to three hours.

The mask can be created with just a thin paper towel, two elastic bands and a stapler. The single-use masks reportedly limit the transmission of droplets, lowering the chances of coronavirus carriers passing on the disease. Staples are used to secure the mask the elastic bands go around the useraposs ears. The creators said the mask should be thrown away after each use. Myczkowska-Szczerska, who heads the Designing Basics faculty at the Krakow Academy of Fine Arts is a specialist in visual communication including papercrafts, posters and book publications. The video is being widely circulated in Poland as everyone in the country is now required to cover their noses and mouths when leaving their homes. Since most of the world went into full blown lockdown, coronavirus hacks aplenty have been keeping citizens in isolation busy.  When lockdown was first announced almost four weeks ago, panic-buyers stripped the shelves of supermarkets bare, fearing goods would dry up. One top tip was to freeze milk in an ice cube tray for tea and coffee to avoid wastage.According toeatbydate , fresh milk can be frozen for three to six months. Though the texture and colour of the milk may change once thawed, it is still safe for consumption. One the milk cube has been thawed at room temperature, it can be added to tea and coffee when desired.

story: NewsDog and cat meat sales surge after medics say natural properties can fight coronavirusDoctors have been telling people in Vietnam and Cambodia that dog and cat meat can help fight illnesses such as Covid-, leading to a spike in sales via takeaway appsShareCommentsByAnna MacSwan:,  APR NewsDog and cat meat sales have soared in Vietnam and Cambodia " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Dog and cat meat sales have soared in Vietnam and Cambodia during the coronavirus pandemic, an animal charity has claimed.Doctors have been telling people that their natural properties can ward off viruses, leading to a surge in demand, according to the animal welfare group FOUR PAWS.An investigation has found that the market is so big that restaurants are even offering dog and cat dishes for takeaway via food delivery apps, the Sun reports.It comes amid fears that the devastating coronavirus, which has now swept across the world, first infected humans at a live animal market in the city of Wuhan in China at the end of last year. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog here Kathrine Polak, a FOUR PAWS veterinarian, says that the shocking practice of eating dogs and cats carries the risk of new illnesses spreading. The unsanitary conditions associated with the cat and dog meat trade, coupled with the contamination risks of having so many dferent animal species caged and killed alongside one another, present the perfect breeding ground for new and deadly diseases, like COVID-, she said. The charity is urging governments to shut down cruel live animal markets, which it describes as ticking time bombs. It says that Phnom Penh, Cambodiaaposs capital, has a shocking  restaurants which serve up dog meat, which has been linked to cases of cholera, trichinella and rabies. But one seller says that in her community, it is believed that eating dogs can prevent colds and viral illnesses. It is claimed that doctors have been encouraging people that it is safe to eat as it is natural, without chemicals. Although Vietnam has a tradition of eating dog meat, Micheal Chour, founder of charity the Sound of Animals, says that the recent rise is also down to Chinese influence.  There was a big increase in the number of Chinese workers coming to the country and they have bought many of their practices along with them, he told the Sun. Many of those, such as torture, have been introduced here and people believe that because China is a big and powerful country, that we should be listening to these practices. Vietnam currently has has  cases of coronavirus while Cambodia has . Neither country has recorded any deaths from the flu-like virus. Wet markets where live animals are sold, slaughtered and skinned, as customers browse the stalls, have reopened across China. The Wuhan wet market, has been widely blamed as the source of the virus, which has killed thousands of people across the world.

title: mum wrestles toddler jaws crocodile
story: NewsMum wrestles toddler from jaws of crocodile by sticking fingers up its noseMaurina Musisinyana, , heard a scream after leaving her children to play on a river bank, and went back to found the crocodile was dragging her son Gideon away into the waterShareCommentsByNadeem Badshah:,  APR NewsMaurina Musisinyana said the attack took place while she was fishing in the crocodile-infested river with her sister while the child and his brother were playing on the riverbank" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA desperate mum wrestled her toddler son from the jaws of a killer crocodile by sticking her fingers up its nose. Maurina Musisinyana, , had left her two children playing under an umbrella on the bank of the Runde River in Zimbabwe while she went fishing nearby. She heard a scream and dashed back to find the umbrella floating in the water – and the crocodile ­dragging away son Gideon, three. Maurina jumped on the beast and used her fingers to block its nose, forcing it to release its grip on the boy. She managed to snatch Gideon away but the crocodile bit her hand. Her boy was rushed to hospital after the horror, near Gonarezhou National Park, with severe bleeding and facial injuries that were making it hard for him to breathe. But he has since made a  full recovery. Maurina, from Chihosi village, Chiredzi, said: “I pressed its nose hard, a tip I learnt from the elders long back.  “If you ­suffocate a crocodile from its nose it loses its strength and that is exactly what I did. I used my other arm to free my baby’s head from its jaws. Even to this day, I still do not believe I rescued my son.”

Fatemeh Khishvand, who became an Instagram star due to her alleged transformation, is said to be on a ventilator and fighting for her le at Sina Hospital in Tehran. The -year-old was detained in October last year amid a crackdown on Instagram celebrities, and faces charges including corruption on earth, encouraging youth to engage in lunacy, insulting the sacred” and “acquiring illicit income”, said activists calling for her release. Lawyers for Ms Khishvand, known on Instagram as Sahar Tabar, had begged a judge to free her due to Iranaposs coronavirus outbreak - the worst in the Middle East - but she was refused bail even though other prisoners have been released following similar concerns. Lawyer Payam Derafshan told the US-based Center for Human Rights in Iran : “We find it unacceptable that this young woman has now caught the coronavirus in these circumstances while her detention order has been extended during all this time in jail. Ms Khishvand faces years in prison for engaging in peaceful freedom of expression on her personal Instagram account, the CHRI added. Iran has suffered one of the worst outbreaks with almost , cases and , deaths reported by Tehran and the country has been accused of grossly under reporting cases and deaths. A parliamentary report said the actual number might be almost twice as many and warned that up to  per cent of the Iranian population could test positive for Coovid-isolation measures are not implemented.  In a worst-case scenario, as many as , could diejust  per cent of containment measures are in place, the report added. Ms Khishvand became an Instagram star in  when she posted photos of her transformation. She claimed she had undergone  surgeries to look like Oscar-winning actress Ms Jolie, . But Instagram users dubbed her a zombie due to her hollow cheeks, upturned nose and gaunt appearance. But she later admitted she had achieved the look through the use of make-up and digital editing, and shared photos of her actual appearance. Her lawyer, Mr Derafshan, said Judge Mohammad Moghiseh repeatedly denied to release her on bail as the coronavirus outbreak worsened, and the judge is now unreachable. Mr Derafshan added: “It’s not the prison director’s fault that she’s behind bars. The responsibility rests with Mr Moghiseh.” Jail officials denied that she had caught the disease.  But Mr Derafshan said: “It seems like it has become a habit for the authorities to deny everything. “It makes no sense to deny this. The prison director should acknowledge the infection and admit she has been hospitalised.” He has called on Tehran to release Ms Khishvand and other prisoners who were detained on allegations of committing non-violent crimes.  He added: “Many women in Shahr-e Rey Prison have contacted my colleague and me about the terrible situation inside the prison and the fear that exists among the inmates [due to the coronavirus]. “We want the authorities to issue a general order to allow these prisoners to be temporarily released. In the absence of judges who are sick or not coming to work, this is the only solution.” The Iran Human Rights Monitor has described Shahre-rey, the prison where Ms Khishvand was detained, as the most dangerous and worst prison for women in the country due to its inhumane medical and psychological conditions. British-Iranian mum Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe, , was among them. Her leave from Evin prison in Tehran was extended to Saturday as the Iranian Prosecutor General considers her plea for clemency. She was ordered to wear an ankle tag and cannot go far from her parentsapos home.  In its most recent update, the Free Nazanin campaign said there was still no update on her appeal clemency. Her father was told to check in again on Saturday to find out whether her furlough would be extended again. One of her former cellmates was on a list of approved clemencies earlier this month. title: dundee demand reconstruction talks after lifting lid on spfl stalemate
story: Dundee have called for reconstruction talks to begin in earnest after lting the lid on their side of the SPFL voting stand-off # but haven#t revealed whether it will be a #yes# or #no# from Dens Park.The Dark Blues today released a y statement detailing their side of the ongoing story that has rocked Scottish football over the past week after days of near silence from managing director John Nelms.In it, the Dens club spoke of clubs being #negatively impacted in two substantial ways# through the SPFL#s resolution proposed last week for which Dundee#s vote is still to be submitted and took aim at the governing body.They called for concrete promises on league reconstruction infor vote in favour of the proposal saying #The centrewill have to accept and support the will of the members# after saying #appetite for reconstruction is there# among clubs across the country.The statement reads: #Good afternoon Dundee fans.  I hope this statement continues to find you safe and healthy as we continue to be quarantined in our fight against the Covid- virus.  The past week has been fraught with anxiety, vitriol, conspiracy theory, and of course a far ranging amount of media conjecture and commentary.  Below is a brief enlightenment of our thoughts and processes over the past week.#Impact of the SPFL resolution:  Relegated clubs were negatively impacted in two substantial ways: the lost opportunity to avoid relegation, and the lost opportunity for financial support.#As we previously stated, the end of the season due to the COVID- epidemic should not result in any club being worse off than they were prior to vote.#In our opinion the SPFL’s “solution” for the league was not a solution for all teams in the league.  Knowing that most teams desperately needed cash flow before the end of April, the quickest and easiest way for the SPFL to achieve that was this proposal however, the result was immediate inequity, and mid-to long-term instability.#Understandably, that was the driving factor for a ‘yes’ vote from many clubs.  Outside of clubs receiving an injection of immediate cash, this was unacceptable to us as we feel the actions of the league should be representative of all its members detrimental impact to one club is ultimately detrimental to all clubs.#Furthermore, the proposal left little prospect for league reconstruction, another signicant aspect of long-term sustainability for Scottish Football.#Whilst the lockdown has resulted in tremendous hardship for the country, one opportunity it has presented, in Dundee FC’s point of view, is the restructuring of the league.#Dundee FC’s vote:  Because of the situation detailed above, it was our intentionto vote ‘no’ on the proposed resolution.#Despite being electronically submitted, for whatever reason, our vote did not reach the centre #We were not aware of that, however, until the SPFL published the ‘results’ of an incomplete vote and it was shown that Dundee FC’s vote was not received.#This raised an immediate red flag for us not only was our vote missing, but we discovered that at least two Premiership clubs had modied their position from the understanding we had the day prior. It was then that we decided to put our foot on the ball and pause.#We conveyed that decision to the centre and ceased taking calls on the subject.  We needed time to develop a clearer DFC view on the situation.#Whilst it is not our responsibility to take the lead on solutions for the league , it is our duty to attempt to ensure that the future of Scottish Football remains promising for all the clubs.#To that end, we have we have worked tirelessly to achieve solutions to help those who were being disadvantaged and sought ways to help them.#We have discussed options with a iety of member clubs to show solidarity to the clubs most negatively impacted by the SPFL proposal.  Relegated clubs must have financial assistance to help soften the landing so they can begin the next season on more equitable footing.#Through our discussions it appears that there is an appetite to provide ious forms of support from other member clubsthese clubs are in fact relegated.  Further details of these acts of kindness and solidarity will be worked out amongst the member clubs.#Also, we are sorry to disappoint all of the conspiracy theorists by saying that we were never exposed to any ‘deals’ from either of the Glasgow giants.  They both acted, as we would expect, with complete professionalism.#Additionally and most importantly for Dundee FC, we spoke to other member clubs regarding their appetite for reconstruction, as the SPFL’s briefing notes does not give us much of a chance and this is the only aspect of any proposal that helps Dundee FC in any way.#There are several things that have to be in place in order to deliver a proper opportunity of achieving a better foundation for Scottish Football’s future.  First, a working group should be assembled and must have members from the highest levels of Scottish Football with long-term interest in the future success of the game.#We need to agree a set of goals that will be the basis of reconstruction which takes into account current and future wants and needs of media member clubs’ financial benefits and sporting integrity as a basis.#It is our belief that after speaking to numerous clubs that the appetite for reconstruction is there and the intention is to set up an immediate and focused working group to take on this task.  The centre will have to accept and support the will of the members.#We do believe the centre has made mistakes in this process, namely not taking into consideration any financial fallout to their member clubs and publishing of the incomplete ballot results, which has put Dundee FC in a position to receive criticism and undue torment.#If what we achieved in our pause was presented by the SPFL in the first instance we would have voted in favour of the proposal.#We would like to thank the fans for their patience, and most of the member clubs for their cooperation and support during this time.  Make no mistake, we continue to have a daunting task ahead of us, but we are encouraged by everyday acts of kindness, resolution, and humanity that we are all sharing as we get through this together.  Stay safe and hope we see you soon in a newly revamped league.#lthr  gtltstronggt🔵 In these Our view on that has not changed.#Over the past few days, we have entered into ious positive discussions with reconstruction at the forefront of these.#Given our discussions and considering all aspects, we don’t feel we are in a position to comment further on the resolution that was put forward.#We understand that this may bring more questions than answers and we will look to give a much more substantial account of the past few days at the conclusion of this process.#Our supporters should know that we are, as always, looking out for the best interests of both Dundee Football Club and Scottish football as a whole.#The Dens Park club issued the statement ahead of an expected SPFL board meeting later on this evening.🔵 In these troubled times, when many people are struggling to get out for their paper, we are pledging to help readers by providing a FREE digital edition of the Eveningfor three months. title: dundee united champions after spfl resolution passes
story: Dundee United have been confirmed as Championship champions after the SPFL#s resolution to #call# the season passed tonight.The league needed % approval from clubs in all four isions for their proposal to go through amid the coronavirus shutdown of Scottish football.Raith Rovers and Cove Rangers were also crowned champions of League One and League Two, respectively, while a resolution for the country#s top flight remains up in the air.After a drawn-out saga, the final result hinged on city rivals Dundee#s vote, with the Dark Blues today saying #yes# to the Hampden chiefs# plans and reconstruction now in the offing.Prior to the outbreak of Covid-, Robbie Neilson#s United had stormed  points clear at the top of the second tier and will now play Premiership football next season.A statement read: “The SPFL has announced that the directors’ written resolution ending Season   in the Ladbrokes Championship, Ladbrokes League  and Ladbrokes League , has been passed with agreement by % of all members.“The announcement comes after the remaining Ladbrokes Championship club signied their agreement to the resolution today resulting in Dundee United FC being declared champions of the Ladbrokes Championship, Raith Rovers FC being declared champions of Ladbrokes League , and Cove Rangers FC being declared champions of Ladbrokes League .”SPFL chairman Murdoch MacLennan added: “Firstly, I want to pass on my warmest congratulations to all three clubs on their successful campaigns. This was a highly unusual end to the season, to say the least, and not the one any of us would have preferred, but all three deserve enormous credit for their performances over the course of the season.“With the turmoil and uncertainty caused by the Covid- outbreak, there was always going to be a highly-charged and passionate debate about how we secure the future of Scottish football.“It is no exaggeration to say that this was an existential matter for Scottish clubs, with many of them telling us they were at real risk of going under unless the situation was resolved very quickly, so I’m pleased that the game has moved decisively.“Whilst more than % of clubs agreed with the directors’ written resolution, it’s clear that others were strongly opposed.“There has been talk of voiding the season, making emergency loans and so on, but what has been agreed today is not just the best way forward, it was the only realistic way forward and I now call on all  clubs to move forward in a constructive and positive way.”SPFL chief executive Neil Doncaster also had his say on tonight’s development.He said: “Prior to this positive result, we were unable to make the vital end-of-season payments, which will provide a leline to so many clubs in the lower isions. From our detailed discussions with clubs, many were facing an enormous cash-flow crisis. We have moved as quickly as possible to try to resolve this unprecedented situation.“We’ve achieved the % agreement threshold in the Ladbrokes Premiership, Championship and Leagues  and  and will now be working as quickly as we can to get the end-of-season payments to members in the three lower isions by the end of this week.”🔵 In these troubled times, when many people are struggling to get out for their paper, we are pledging to help readers by providing a FREE digital edition of the Eveningfor three months. story: These are troubled times which will change the way we all live and work, at least for the time being.At the Tele we are determined to continue to serve our communities, bringing you vital information you can trust, free from the barrage of “fake news” often served up on social media s.During this period we also want you to see the Tele as a friend and companion, whether you areWe realise these are extraordinary times and we need to take extraordinary measures to ensure we reach our readers.That is why we have decided to make our ePaper subscription pack FREE to everyone for a period of three months.If you choose to sign up, there will be no charge for three months – and before that period expires or any expense is incurred, we will be in touch to seeyou wish to continue with your subscription.
